results.title: Al Qaeda Branch in Somalia Threatens Americans in East Africa — and Even the U.S.

multimedia.caption: The Shabab control large parts of Somalia and raise considerable funds through local taxation and extortion. The group has carried out deadly attacks not only in Somalia but also in Kenya and Uganda.

results.title: So You Bought Someone a Gadget. Here’s How Not to Become Their Tech Support.
results.abstract: It feels like the easiest gift until it needs a reboot, restart or anything else.

results.title: Burnout Isn’t Just in Your Head. It’s in Your Circumstances.
results.abstract: We can fight emotional exhaustion by decreasing demands, increasing support and enhancing control.

results.title: How to Have a Successful Virtual Happy Hour
results.abstract: The coronavirus has turned drinks at the bar into drinks in our individual homes, but that doesn’t mean you have to drink alone.

results.title: Wondering About Social Distancing?
results.abstract: Answers to your most common questions about the best practices for stemming the tide of the coronavirus pandemic.

results.title: Parents Need Stress Relief, Too
results.abstract: We’re all anxious. Here are ways to cope.

results.title: How ‘One Day at a Time’ Came Back From the Brink
results.abstract: The beloved sitcom, canceled last year by Netflix, premieres Tuesday on its new home, Pop TV. But it took more than just fan passion for it to get a second chance.
des_facet: One Day at a Time (TV Program)

multimedia.caption: “One Day at a Time” returns on Pop TV this week, just over a year after Netflix canceled it. From left, Justina Machado, Rita Moreno, Stephen Tobolowsky, Todd Grinnell,  Isabella Gomez and Marcel Ruiz during filming for this season’s Halloween episode.

results.title: Why Birds Are the World’s Best Engineers
results.abstract: A nest is “a disordered stick bomb,” resilient in ways that humans have hardly begun to understand, much less emulate.

results.title: Hundreds of Scientists Scramble to Find a Coronavirus Treatment
results.abstract: In an ambitious international collaboration, researchers have “mapped” proteins in the coronavirus and identified 50 drugs to test against it.
